newsitem.title: INDIA: Canada hopes telecoms will boost trade with India.
newsitem.headline: Canada hopes telecoms will boost trade with India.

text.p: Canada hopes to boost trade with India through high-technology exports, particularly telecommunication equipment, following a telephone service contract won by Bell Canada, Canadian officials said on Friday.

"We..see telecom equipment as an area of huge potential," Canadian High Commissioner Stanley Gooch told a news conference addressed by Foreign Minister Lloyd Axworthy, who was in Calcutta to attend a business conference.

"The Bell-Tata communications project in Andhra Pradesh will be a major factor in boosting Canadian investment," Axworthy told the conference. Canada, the ninth largest foreign investor in India, hoped to move up the ladder, he said.
Bell Canada and India's Tata group have jointly won a licence to provide telephone services in southern Andhra Pradesh state.
Axworthy said Indian Communications Minister Beni Prasad Varma had assured him of India's decision to pass a law to empower a telecommunications regulator.
"The minister indicated that there would be legislation dealing with a regulatory authority," Axworthy said.

The Tata-Bell consortium had joined other licence winners in opposing what they termed as high charges for private companies to connect to the network of the state-run Department of Telecommunications (DoT), India's telephone monopoly.
They were also concerned about what some critics saw as uneven competition with the DoT without an independent regulator in place.
India opened up telephone services to private firms under an economic reform programme launched in 1991.

Gooch said he expected Canada to export environmental technology and aircraft in addition to traditional exports like newsprint, wood pulp and fertilisers. A turnaround was expected in newsprint exports after a slowdown in 1995, he added.
Canada expected India to export more computer software to add to traditional exports of textiles, jewellery and pharmaceuticals, Gooch said.
Bilateral trade totalled Canadian $ 1.0 billion ($750 milion) in 1995, Gooch said adding India had a surplus of C$100 million ($75 million).

Canada will open diplomatic offices in the Indian cities of Calcutta and Chandigarh, Canadian officials said. Canada already has a trade office in Madras, in addition to its high commission (embassy) in New Delhi.
